Message.Title: As of 8/13 ZACKS reasons to BUY..1
Message.Msg: NVIDIA has a strong position in the market for high-end discrete graphics, especially for the gaming segment of the market. Its GeForce line of graphics cards is essential for playing some of the most popular computer games today. We expect NVIDIA to maintain its advantage in the gaming segment in the foreseeable future. This apart, recently the company launched the GeForce GTX 570 and GTX 560 Ti, the most advanced GPUs for gamers. This enhancement in the GeForce series is expected to attract more customers in the near future, increasing NVIDIA s market share. This integration of the CPU with the GPU is expected to result in a power efficient chip, which may help the company to further strengthen its position in the gaming market. Moreover, in March 2011, the company introduced NVIDIA PhysX technology. This was first incorporated by Funcom's Dreamworld 2.5, a leading game engine for massively multi-player online games (MMOGs). Dreamworld Engine 2.5 will help double the speed of in-game physics processing compared to the traditional client-side PhysX technology. Hence, the demand for the abovementioned graphics card is expected to increase both from local manufacturers and International players. NVIDIA being the market leader is expected to grab a major chunk of this pie.

Message.Title: ZACKS reason to BUY Part 2
Message.Msg: Although gaming is the key to NVIDIA s growth, computing is becoming increasingly more visual, given the new-age tablets that are seeing tremendous demand. Software increasingly relies on a visual user interface rather than text. For example, Windows 7 requires much more graphics resources than its predecessor as it leverages improved graphics capabilities to improve user experience. This trend is very positive for a company like NVIDIA, which is the leading producer of graphics cards with a very broad range of products.

Topic.Title: How big of a position do you guys have?

Message.Msg: I'm holding 14,600 shares and as of now 30 Aug 13 calls I picked up for .72 so atleast they doubled. I picked up a few thousand shares at high 9's but the majority on the way down from 26 at the average price of $13sh so I'm only up 12% overall. I've been holding NVDA for over 10 years right after they started. Its been boom times and bust times many times after I learned about options in 2004 and made a ton of money, all of which I lost in March of 2005 with the market downturn. :) I'm a strong believer in the company and Jen, and I'm more excited going forward with their success in the mobile space. For such a small company to have such massive market penetration against the likes of TI and Qualcomm really shows you their innovation. Best of Luck with your trades! Higgins

Topic.Title: Toshiba cancels ARM-based computer

Message.Msg: - "Toshiba Corp. has cancelled plans to sell computers that run the Windows RT operating system from Microsoft Corp. and that are based on an ARM-based processor, due to delays in getting adequate supplies of components, according to reports. There has been much discussion of low yields and shortages of supply of 28-nm silicon during this year. Executives with... Nvidia... have spoken out about their Inability to get enough 28-nm chips from TSMC and that the undersupply was expected to last through until the fourth quarter of 2012." Sounds like yet another nvidia management screw-up, boys. Remember when Jen was publicly throwing TSMC's Mr. Chang under the bus for this and that? And now Jen can't get the chips he wants from TSMC! See any cause and effect there? Hummm? -

Topic.Title: Toshiba cancels ARM-based computer

Message.Msg: Nothing against your posting it, but the title of this article doesn't sound right. Toshiba had no choice but to cancel it because OMAP4470 couldn't get MS certification in time for the October 26 launch. Same was the case with HP quitting Win RT - no viable SoC to work with. (at least not in June, when HP announced its decision) Some of the tech writers are plain clueless.

Topic.Title: Toshiba is basically kicked out of the Win RT club

Message.Msg: Vendors' default without compromising RT standard is a good thing. At launch, it's better to weed out the 2nd tier and 3rd tier products. WIthout Microsoft Surface, NVDIA alone would not do it, but this wouldn't be the case. Got to do it right from the beginning. A slightly slower uptake (which I doubt) will be much better than a faster uptake followed by collapsing due to quality issues. GOt it now?

Topic.Title: Toshiba is basically kicked out of the Win RT club

Message.Msg: "GOt it now? " Never didn't get it... but glad you agree... now "NVDIA alone would not do it"

Topic.Title: Toshiba is basically kicked out of the Win RT club

Message.Msg: To add another point: variety of OEM presence without uniformly high quality does NOT ensure consumers acceptance or embrace. Take the early Android tablets as an example, we were certainly not in a shortage of OEM representation, but none of them made a dent on the Apple dominated market until Nexus 7 and some other late ASUS model came along....we are now just beginning to see the light of the day. So, coming back to my point, you don't need MANY, you just need the winners - this goes for OEMs as well as products.

Topic.Title: Toshiba is basically kicked out of the Win RT club

Topic.Title: huge nvda writeup, nobody posts this???

Message.Msg: - In excerpts. "I will go point-by-point in countering Tegra’s prospective drivers, and give you reasons why the stock still doesn’t look like a convincing investment. The Surface and the Nexus 7: Not Enough NVIDIA’s Vice-President of Investor Relations, Rob Csongor, said that the quad-core Tegra 3 is popping up in “some of the world’s most exciting mobile devices.“ The names he took after that – the Google (NASDAQ: GOOG) Nexus 7, the Microsoft (NASDAQ: MSFT) Surface and a quad-core, LTE powered, smartphone by Fujitsu that’s selling in Japan. If I have to call some mobile devices exciting, it would be the iPhone and the iPad from Apple (NASDAQ: AAPL) and Samsung’s high-end smartphones. The Nexus 7 has opened to terrific reviews, and has been doing so well that Google has had trouble keeping up with demand. But the Nexus is no iPad or a Samsung tablet and I don’t expect it to propel NVIDIA’s top line through the sky. Again, if we are talking of a 7-inch tablet, the discussion would remain incomplete without a mention of the next generation Kindle Fire from Amazon (NASDAQ: AMZN), which is rumored to be powered by the Tegra. The Nexus 7 has been primarily aimed at the spot after the iPad, which Kindle Fire successfully held last year. With a refreshed version on the way, Nexus 7 will again have some serious competition to contend with. Although NVIDIA would be happy to see its chips inside both the #2 tablet contenders, competition among the two might also have a negative effect on one of them. Also, I can’t finish talking about 7-inch tablets without making a reference to the purported iPad mini from Apple. If Cupertino does decide to come to the 7-inch tablet party, and there’s a good chance of that, the Nexus 7’s and the Kindle Fire’s prospects will certainly be dented big time. And again, as I said, NVIDIA is competing through tablets belonging to the second rung of the ladder so far, way behind what Apple and Samsung sell. And finally, how successful the Surface from Microsoft will turn out to be is a big doubt. To me, it seems an experimental product at best which is trying to strike a fine balance between a computer and a tablet. Consumer acceptance of the Surface will play a major role in driving NVIDIA but what price consumers would like to pay for Microsoft’s latest adventure remains to be seen. Where are the smartphones? What I’m going to write here would seem like an extended story of the previous part. “Illustrious” smartphones powered by NVIDIA are the HTC One X and the Fujitsu phone mentioned earlier. If these are flagships on which the company is looking to ride the mobile boom, chances of success would take a solid beating. A Samsung Galaxy design win would have given me some solace as NVIDIA is far away from an iPhone slot since Apple uses its own chips. But Samsung, which used to be NVIDIA’s customer, has also gone in-house with its Exynos processor. With both the smartphone and tablet bellwethers looking away from NVIDIA, I don’t see much space for the company to flex its muscles in the mobile revolution as of now." Poor little Tegra. None of the Big Buyers want it. Kinda like the stock too, right boys? -

Topic.Title: As expect NVIDIA will dominate Windows RT launch

Message.Msg: you seriously think that not just Dell and Samsung, but also Asus and Lenovo, will launch their devices if they know that msft is launching Surface RT at $200? say a nothing launch units on hand of 100K devices, $300 cost ($200 hardware plus $100 for windoz) = $30M sunk into something that absolutely positively will not sell sitting next to a $200 Surface. You can be pretty sure Asus, Lenovo et al will want firm Surface pricing commitment from msft before they sign POs for their tablets. Toshiba is smelling like a rose.

Topic.Title: As expect NVIDIA will dominate Windows RT launch

Message.Msg: this is an article by VR_Zone, published on July 26th, merely 3 weeks from today. It comments on Snapdragon's readiness (NOT!) for Windows RT. ""In any case, Qualcomm is becoming more aggressive. However, it seems that the company still isn't there (yet), given the rumored issues with Windows 8 drivers and the ongoing aggressive acquisition of new talent ,""" Read more: http://vr-zone.com/articles/next-gen-qualcomm-adreno-hardware-has-unified-shaders-opengl-es-3.0-compliant/16824.html#ixzz23ffNJyYl

Message.Title: Apple iPads Gain 11.5% Market Share in 2Q
Message.Msg: - Apple iPads Gain 11.5% Market Share in 2Q Remember how the paid pumper boys were sayin' that those knock-off Android tablets would continue to take market share away from the Genuine Apple iPads? They were wrong. It hasn't happened. On the contrary, Apple's iPad actually GAINED 11.5% market share during the second quarter of 2012. Yep. Apple took +11.5% market share in just the last 90 days, boys. And that's BEFORE the industry crushing iPad Mini is released in just a few weeks. Apple might get to like 95% of the entire tablet market at this rate. http://www.digitimes.com/news/a20120815PR203.html "Apple during the second quarter shipped 17 million iPad 2 and new iPad media tablets, up 44.1% from 11.8 million in the first quarter, according to the HIS. This industry-leading increase in shipments translated into a market share gain of 11.5 percentage points, as Apple's second-quarter global tablet share climbed to 69.6%." "In July of this year, Apple exceeded the 85 million mark for iPad tablets sold since the product's launch in April of 2010. In contrast, Samsung, Apple's closest competitor, has shipped [a mere] 13 million total tablets." There is no mention of the cummulative production for the other stastically insignificant little Android tablet makers. WOW! An 11.5% market share gain by Apple in just the last 90 days. That's a MASSIVELY LARGE, ENORMOUSLY HUGE GAIN, right boys? It sure is. -

Topic.Title: Apple iPads Gain 11.5% Market Share in 2Q

Message.Msg: The point of the article is that the tablet market is still units infancy, and NVDA based products such as Surface and Nexus 7 could unseat Apples dominance. In tge cery near term. Good point
